The smell is rich with roasted goodness. You pick up on a lot of roasted grains and malts. Then a nice mix of hop bitterness at the end to tie it all together. So far Old Rasputin is a nice inviting brew. Now for the taste, it is Bold an Rich with flavors. You first pick on all the roasted goodness. Lots of nice smooth roasted malts and grains. The body of Old Rasputin is a medium to heavy. Not to heavy but definitely a lot heavier than other Stouts on the market. It is hard to pick up on the 9.00% ABV in this brew, it goes down just that smooth. This brew would go nice with dinner or on a cold winter day. The mouth feel is Rich, Bold, Roasted, Clean, Smooth, and Refreshing. Overall I am going to give Old Rasputin a 4.25 out of 5. I would definitely look this brew up again giving the opportunity to. North Coast Brewing Co., did a super nice job with this Russian Imperial Stout.

This beer has been around for years and years, if it’s on a restaurant menu and you love stouts you’re probably going to order this. It’s everytning you want in a stout. Deep dark licorice in color, strong smell of coffee and molasses, a rich full flavor with the bite of a stout. It’s a really good stout, but you probably already knew that.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass at 45 degrees,  Appearance: A completely black pour with a good amount of carbonation and head. (4.00)  Aromas: A strong bittersweet chocolate and roasted coffee and root beer aroma predominate, I would describe similar to a cold brew coffee, but slightly more roasted and sweet. There are some sweet bread aromas that come forward at the end. (4.25)  Flavor: Flavor mostly of semi-sweet chocolate, but roasted barley malts giving it a bitter coffee flavor and root beer is here too. There is a breaded, caramel and toffee malt presence underneath. A dried citrus flavor may be present underneath all of the darker flavors. The hop bitterness is strong with comparatively mild chocolate and citrus sweetness. A subtle coffee background comes forward. The alcohol is pronounced and stands out at 9%. The bitterness seems to perfectly balance the sweetness so that this captures a strong dark-chocolate flavor, but is complemented nicely by the bitter hops. The balance here is perfect. (4.50)  Feel: A good amount of carbonation and heavy, oily body due to the ABV allowing it to go down particularly smooth for the strong bitterness. An oily bittersweet-chocolate flavor lingers on the tongue, however an astringent hop bitterness lingers at the same time. Again, so well balanced between bitter and sweet. (4.25)  Compared side by side the the Yeti by Great Divide: This one has more of a bitter and less sweet chocolate flavor. More breaded and less roasted. Slightly stronger hop bitterness. There might actually be some citrus fruit underneath. More balanced overall between sweetness, bitterness, and body. Lighter body, more carbonation, and less syrup & oil. With the balance, hides the alcohol much better. Finishes soo smooth, which deceptively hides the alcohol and makes it very drinkable.  Compared to Sierra Nevada's Narwhal 2019 on 1/16/22: Pours a similar color with a slightly lighter head. More earthy black malt, root beer, and molasses notes. Less chocolate and earthy espresso roast. Cleaner and slightly lighter.  Compared to Stone Imperial Stout 3/2023: Pours a similar color, lighter head. More bittersweet cocoa, English black malt, cream. Less dark chocolate and bitter pine. Dryer and cleaner.  Overall - This seems like a strong representation of an imperial stout at an affordable price. The bittersweet chocolate flavor in the hops is pronounced, but just enough chocolate malt to hide the ABV relatively well without incorporating any unnecessary sweetness. The balance of sweetness, body, and hop biterness is perfected such that the alcohol is hidden and this drinks so deceptively smooth. When I want a Russian imperial stout on a cold winter's night, this is the one I grab. A delicious imperial stout that is appropriately sweet, and appropriately balanced with hop bitterness.

This beauty pours a licorice black body with a slim tan head that dissipates into a thin skim. The nose is all about strong coffee, roasted grains, burnt sugar cookies and molasses. The flavor mirrors the aroma along with some dark toasted pumpernickel. The mouthfeel is medium light with just a slight carbonated sizzle on the tail-end. Overall this is an intense and satisfying stout that stands out of the crowded field and clubbers your taste buds into submission with every pull.

Having a classic, and it deserves the title.  Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass. Very dark brown with a nice beige head and and great curtain lacing. Pleasant chocolate smell and taste. Toasted pumpernickel and a hint of coffee. Not boozy and very drinkable. Great beer!
I don't usually love stouts, but this is something else. Subtle notes of chocolate with a lot of back of the tongue bite. Keeps you kicking well after you should be drowned.

Pours black/brown with thick tan head, a model stout look. Body is a bit thin and not at all heavy like a lot of other imperial stouts. Taste is a nice liquorice, coffee. For me this is the imperial stout I judge all others, a classic, not too busy and satisfying. Cheers !

Good dark color, but a smaller head for a stout. Smells toasty toasted malts, chocolate and coffee. Taste smooth and flavorful for a stout. Bitter. Pretty standard for a stout. Hides the 9% well. Not quite as creamy as I would expect. Overall a solid stout but not my favorite.

Tasting a bottle from a 4 pack...This beer is inky black in my pint glass with a roasted/chocolaty flavor. Some bitterness in the taste profile but not overwhelming. Slight head with good lacing on the glass. Someone else who rated it said it was their benchmark stout and I can see why. This is my first time tasting it and it's great, I'll be back.
Got a four pack of 12 ounce bottles, just gives you a great weighty buzz. An absolute darling, and would get it more but it is usually just out of my price range.

Get it! This is the imperial stout I use as a baseline to compare all imperial stouts. It’s aggressive, slightly bossy, and right on the edge of my bitterness threshold. This beer will make a man/lesbian out out of you!
Dark, rich complexity...hoppy, chocolate and coffee notes and thick, sweet mouthfeel. I’m not a huge stout guy but I recognize the greatness of this beer!
Rich brown black color with tan creamy head and curtains of lacing. Sharp roasted malt flavor, molasses with burnt sugar and bread. Some notes of olive too.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a Dogfish Head tulip  L: Dark, dark pour... nearly black with thick fluffy tannish head. Great lacing.  S: Roasted grains and burned sugars.  T/F: Follows the nose. Strong roast character... sweet charred sugars, bitter roast, espresso, and dark chocolate. Smooth and creamy mouthfeel. Medium bodied... oily... roast bitterness carries throughout with some sweetness to soften the finish.  O: A solid Russian Imperial. Really good flavor... very pleasing and drinkable for such a big beer.

The hype is real. Normally, I dont like imperial russian stouts -finding them too heavy (feel & taste) and bitter, but this is a work of art.  Looks.. Well my phone flashlight is just a tiny brown dot through the pint glass. Smells very chocolately and roasty Tastes.. Very chocolately and roasty - big malts that give it a robust flavor with very present but very well balanced bitterness. Feels very very wide and smooth, but with balance.. it doesnt weight you down but rather takes its time. The 9+% abv is well hidden and takes its time as well - definitely not a session beer!!  Overall, it's bold yet balanced, powerful yet measured, deep yet drinkable. As I said, the hype is real.

Reviewed 12/2/22  From a 12oz bottle into a pint glass. As near as I can interpret with the bottle code 21381028, the date is 10/28/22-this is pretty fresh.  Pours pitch black with about two and a half fingers of tan head. Excellent retention and lacing.  Smells mainly of coffee and a hint of dark chocolate. Aromas are faint.  Taste is slightly sweeter. Chocolate and coffee dominate.  Slight bitter aftertaste. Low carbonation Medium to full bodied but thinner than other RIS's.  This was a gateway beer for me into bigger stouts. Don’t know why I don’t revisit more often. Excellent beer.

Recently, I was devastated when Tallgrass no longer shipped their Buffalo Sweat oatmeal stout. I tried many different brews, including Convict Hill, Nitro, Samuel Smith ($$$) and a couple others but they just didn't live up to it. Guiness for me had no body or that nice roasted flavor. I stumbled on this one by happen chance. It was full bodied, robust, nice head and had no undesirable aftertaste. It is now my go-to brew.
javascript:void(0);

Was stunned to realize I hadn't reviewed this one, having had it several times before in my life.  Very dark brown, pours decent sized tan head, creamy and lingering.  Chocolate, raisin, coffee aromas dominate for me initially. A rich, sweet roasty aroma.  Quite malty sweet up front, with some of the chocolate and dark fruit noted in the aroma. Roast and bitterness is present early, but stays somewhat muted compared to some imperial stouts. Finishes with the roast taking over, but the malt sweetness never completely ceases. A delicious stout without being overpoweringly stouty.  Full body and moderate carbonation. No astringency, and a mellow warming. Might prefer a lower carbonation level.  Always a favorite imperial stout of mine due to its drinkability. Some RIS examples are over the top in terms of alcohol and roast. This one is not.

A: Pours a tan one finger head. Completely opaque, almost solidly black except the edges which are a dark dark brown. Beautiful lacing, but dissipates too soon.  S: Chocolate, coffee, heavy roast, alcohol, dark fruit, raisins, malt  T: Wow this is an intense brew. The roasted bitterness hits you immediately, tempered by the mellow creaminess of the chocolate. Ends with a good burnt breadiness.  O: I used the word bitter many times in the review, because this beer highlights how to use bitterness to create depth and flavor without overpowering everything else. This is an intense but smooth brew. Big on flavor, easy to drink. One heck of a stout.
This rating is for the nitro version. The nitro has a better feel and a ton more lacing. Pretty

Taste: I had the Nitro version on tap recently, rich creamy, hint of sweet,chocolate, coffee, dry toasted malt finish. Same with the nose. Black, opaque, tan refined nitro head. Medium/full body. Better than I remembered. 70 IBUs

Poured from 12oz bottle into glass. Possible date stamp on label is '81330709'. This is a 2018 produced beer. Black colored body, with some dark brown and ruby brown edges when back lit. Aggressive pour brought forth a one finger, puffy, khaki colored head. Each sip leaves behind a few scattered spots of lacing. Well balanced aroma of dark roasted malts with char, coffee, and chocolate. Out of the char is a whiff of dark dried fruits. Taste is dark roasted malts that express deep dark chocolate, burnt coffee, and a hint of soaked, dark dried fruit. Quite the smooth and creamy mouth feel. Very enjoyable. Okay carbonation. Not overly bitter. Tremendous balance of the flavors lead to a very pleasant drinking experience. Very easy to take repeated sips in short order. Bitterness is kept very low and the char stays at the end, but the slight sweetness of the malts balance this out. There is a companion component of brighter hops that add well to the mix and balance.

I'll say if you like a stout this is it best one out there the right body and heat from the alchol mixing with the darl malt and notes of the beer amazing this is the best stout ive ever had bar none if you like stouts this is one to try

Poured 12oz bottle into snifter glass. 9% abv.  Appearance- Pours a dark charcoal in color, high light brown head that sticks to glass.  Smell- chocolate, coffee, and vanilla round out the aroma.  Taste- Lots of malt up front, turning more chocolate as the flavor goes on. Lots of coffee notes into a bitter finish which is quite smoky as well.  Mouthfeel- Heavy in body, medium carbonation.  Overall- A really good RIS with ample flavor and complexity. True to the style. This would be great aged.
Nice stout and a pleasure to sip. Enjoyed on draft at the brewery. Smooth and easy to drink.

Black, creamy beige head. Sticky lacing. Great retention.  Aromas of spresso, roasted malts and bitter chocolate. Slight fresh hop presence too.  Taste follows the nose. That 'fresh' hop being more prominent than other RIS. Intense flavours.  Medium to full bodied. Bitter roasted coffee aftertaste.  Great beer!

12oz bottle poured into a snifter glass…  =====  Look Poured brown-black with a 4 finger mocha head. A ton of activity on the build up, similar to a Guinness, an amazing brew.  Smell Smell is espresso, nutty, roasted malt, and vanilla, with a bittersweet toffee finish.  Taste Taste is the same as smell, and very well balanced—just the right flavor and finish.  Mouthfeel Heavy, soft, velvety smooth body, with a nice carbonation.  ===== With the exception a Deschutes Abyss I once had on tap, THIS is the Russian Imperial Stout I go back to time and again—and the one I measure all others by. It’s a full-bodied and filling sipper for the right occasion.
Strong stout. Not as smooth as a breakfast stout and also not a stout for beginners. It’s strong taste has everything the seasoned stout connoisseur loves.

Classic American example of the RIS style. Complex roasted malt character, black char and chocolate and earthy bitterness. It has some edginess to it rather than just being creamy smooth, though I imagine it would mellow out after some time in the bottle.
What a fantastic Russian Imperial Stout!! Will definitely have again!
Rates up there with Samuel Smith ris,and ahead of Lenikugel RIS which is no longer brewed.Excellent work fellas,you got a winner!

I agree with other reviewers stating that it is more of medium bodied stout than a full bodied stout. Believe it or not the first thing that I am smelling is some hops. I hope this is not a bad thing. the bourbon barrel aged version smells better. I also agree with this one particular beer reviewer stating that Old Rasputin tastes similar to a dark chocolate covered black cherry. Moreover, Old Rasputin has one of the best label design artwork that I have noticed. I did not notice a date on the bottle I had thought that North Coast Brewing Co. did put dates on their products, oh well a non adjunct RIS should not go bad too soon so, I won't take off points for that this time around. I am detecting some hop presence, but it's nothing inadmissible. This is a great laid back west coast style approach to a RIS style. I appreciate the adjuncts like coffee or chocolate, but sometimes I want to drink 2 or 3 bottles of a RIS that is not going to make me feel edgy & irritated. I can see why this is considered a benchmark in the earlier American craft beer days, with this beer sort of having a style of its own. I agree this is an overstated RIS, matter of fact this taste more like a black IPA. I'm very disappointed with the Old Rasputin. North Coast needs to work on revising this recipe big time. Furthermore, I would like to try this on tap sometime. Cheers! B
Dark stout that tastes lighter. Smooth and delicious  Second time not quite as impressive. Want to try again

Like many people Guinness Export Stout was my first stout. I actually remember many Black and Tans with Bass usually the tan. Then I was introduced to Old Rasputin and the crazy notion that a stout from California surpassed my longtime favorite. Some 20 years later this beer is relevant because its attributes, a semi dry english style stout distinguished by the right amount of carbonation makes it that every day after work stout, like a Guinness, albeit with an abv at 9%. The score reflects the incredibly cheap 4 pack price of around 10 bucks!

Excellent stout, easy to find and ages well. BUT.....since I'm not a big stout fan, I'll usually go with Founders Breakfast Stout when feeling like one. The Founders has this one beat by miles....at least for me.
Great in a bottle but outstanding on tap (nitro pour only).
Fantastic example of an RIS.
A long-time favorite. Good to try in Fort Bragg, goes well with the foggy seascapes -- warming, aromatic and bih=g rich taste. Travels well too -- one of my favorites in our local pub in Georgia.

Rather a classic among American RIS’s, it deserves its reputation. It’s just a shade below absolute, opaque black, with a nice creamed coffee head. Aroma is malty sweet and cocoa dry. The taste brings it all back home, weaving a genuinely classic stout from strands of bitter chocolate, dark, dark espresso, a hint of mineral ash, raisins and fresh cookies. Excellent feel that allows the long finish to linger appropriately. I’ve been enjoying this beer for years; it’s dependably excellent. It ages very well and it’s really great on tap too.

North Coast Old Rasputin RIS - 9% ABV - 75 IBUs Date: 06/21/18, enjoyed on 09/03/18. Appearance: Black, not used motor oil black but a standard stout color with two fingers of mocha colored head. There is some slight ruby red color seeping in around the edges. Aroma: Big roasted malt aromas, slight char, and bitter dark chocolate, all with a coffee undercurrent. It actually smells a little sweet, like rich cacao powder. Taste: As with the nose, the boldest flavor are these big malty notes followed by a slightly sweet and that dark chocolate taste. There is a beautiful ashy quality to the malts that really works wonderfully. The finish on Old Rasputin is quite bitter, letting those IBUs really shine through. It has a medium full mouthfeel with an almost velvet texture, but it does feel lighter than say Bell's Expedition Stout. Tons of dark roast coffee and bittersweet chocolate notes come out as the beer reaches room temperature. Biased comments: Wow, this is still one impressive beer and certainly is one of my favorite stouts. After the explosion in popularity of adjunct filled beers and pastry stouts, it is very refreshing to return to a beer that is the antithesis of all that. Also, North Coast must be one of the most underrated breweries on the planet. All of their beers that I’ve had are quality beers, and that isn’t something I can say for very many breweries. This beer in particular is a good deal better than many of the whales I have managed to chase down and is available nearly everywhere for less than $10, and its Non-GMO as well!

Intense malty and hoppy character. Has a unique flavor compared to other imperial russian stouts that is hard to describe. This beer is not for everyone. It is extremely bitter. I can't seem to understand why some people seem to think more flavor=better. While this beer is worth trying at least once it's not something you would want to drink often. Most of these stronger flavored beers are overrated due to beer-snobs. The rating of this beer is higher than it should be. CHEERS!
Well, this is an instant classic. “Imperial” stout, so this beer packs a big punch. Almost tastes like some grog, but deliciously. This beer is daaaark.

Unknown vintage; drank 7/29/18 @ the Yarchives.  Black/brown appearance.  A violent pour yielded a HUGE dark tan head; thick tree-rung lace.  Fresh earth, medium roast coffee bean & hop bite notes in the nose.  Creamy medium thick mouthfeel.  Medium roast coffee bean & hop bite flavors up front; fresh earth notes on the finish.  Too hop forward for me to really love; this is practically a Cascadian dark ale.

I have a wide range of what I like, pretty much everything.  This. Fucking. Beer. Is. So. Disgusting.  I picked a bottle up with a mixed six pack and put it in the fridge, had a Guinness to compare it to, well when time came.  I took one sip and this literally made me vomit. I don't think I've ever drank something more vile in my life. The other reviews made this sound awesome and I'm sure it is for people who exclusively drink Stouts, but if that's not what you normally drink, leave this alone.  Sincerely, a guy who loved Stouts who is now put off by them because of this.
Exceptional quality.
The espresso of imperial stout with dark chocolate hints.
Had on nitro at a local brew barbeque joint. Cuz im a tryin anything and everything on nitro. Enjoyed it and recommend.
awful swill
Pours very dark with a nice tan head. Well carbonated. Smell is coffee, brown sugar, licorice. Taste is coffee, chocolate, licorice. Alcohol is up front. A tad bit bitter.
Pours a dark black with a brown/tan color to the foam. Aroma is of dark chocolate and roastyness. Taste is much the same with a bitter, almost harsh roasty flavor. Fun to sip and contemplate.

Deep and dark color, significant head and lacing  Malty smell with a bit of chocolate and licorice  Delicious mix of malts, licorice, hops , and chocolate for a vivid taste with a pleasant bitter aftertaste  Full bodied and deep mouthfeel  One of my favorite beers, but the alcohol content is a bit high for drinking more than one or two at a time

This is a decent beer. The price is good and the taste is pretty good also. I don't think it has the complexity of other beers I've tasted (but those other beers cost a lot more too). Very worth it for the price. North Coast is a good brewer. I like all there products so far.
12oz bottle into an 8oz snifter at the Brass Tap here in Baltimore

Aggressive pour into a Duvel tulip glass. 2.5 fingers of creamy mocha head that lingered for a few minutes then dissipated. Typical stout black color. Nose is chocolate, alcohol, very faint coffee, and slight toffee. Taste follows the smell and alcohol is pretty strong making this beer seem stronger than it is (is this 9% or 12%?). Slight burn in the aftertaste which gives way to faint hints of chocolate and an even fainter taste of fruit. Mouthfeel is surprisingly not sticky. I am fairly new to this style but this is one I would have again, although in moderation.
Not my favorite, but a solid porter

One of my favorite beers. Dark look, tan head, beautiful lacing. Smells of chocolate and coffee. Taste of hints of chocolate, strong coffee, and roasted malts, bitter, but a dynamic taste. This isn't a beer you are going to chug, but one you should enjoy over an evening. Complex and beautiful. Don't rush it, enjoy each sip.

Updated 11/26/20 Enjoyed this tonight at roughly 50 degrees temp. Look: jet black absence of light. Pours with a nice inch plus tannish head Smell: roasted malts, molasses, coffee Taste: starts with a nice carbonation and roasted malts and molasses slightly sweet and then finishes with hints of coffee and a pleasant slightly bitter finish. Very complex and oh so good! Feel: great carbonation and thick bodied Overall: this beer is outstanding in all versions! It won’t disappoint!  The very first RIS I tried and I was hooked! It is the one beer I always try to keep in stock and if I was going to rate would always be in my all time top 10 RIS. I’m having one right now! Well Done!

In all fairness to this one I'm very new to this . I have only started with the Porters and Stouts in the last year so I don't think my palate was mature enough. I will give this one another try down the road because I see it has some wonderful reviews. The look was amazing the smell was fantastic but just to much depth I think for my taste at this time.

Poured into a tall clear pint glass. Has a very dark brown appearance. Gorgeous finger-thick fluffy tan head, tons of lacing.  Smells of high % cocoa chocolate, mocha/espresso, cream, vanilla, and roasted malts.  Much like the aroma. Cocoa chocolate, toffee, roasted coffee beans, mocha/espresso, dark fruit, licorice, alcohol is present, spicy hops, burn malt. Bitter roasted malt aftertaste.  Smooth feel.

From a 12oz bottle. Pours black with a finger of tan head. Smells of roasted malt and chocolate. Heavy, creamy feel. Rich coffee and chocolate flavors with a finish of hop bitterness. Outstanding, and the best part is that it's widely available.
Pours black with two fingers of tan head. Smells roasty with some dark fruits. Taste follows, lots of dark chocolate. Dark fruits, mildly bitter dark roasted finish. Overall a great classic RIS.

Very excited to try this beer after hearing a lot about its reputation. Nice dark black color with some lingering foamy head and lacing. Smells faintly of coffee and chocolate, tastes of dark chocolate, dark coffee, some malt and hoppiness without much bitterness. Very smooth and creamy mouthfeel, trace lingering hoppy bitterness in the aftertaste. A nice enjoyable stout.
4 pack bought in Fort Bragg, CA. 03-2018

Update: Read my review out loud like a 70’s porn star  Ohhh rich, dark and dirty goodness...almost sounds like an adult film. This stout will wreck you. It’ll leave you disappointed...with 90% of every other stout you drink. Pours dark and void of any light. Smells like deep, dark coffee and chocolate. If it sounds like I’m in love with this beer, then your reading it correctly. Albeit it’s darker then Samuel L. Jackson in Pulp Fiction, it drinks remarkably smooth and refreshing! I would definitely recommend this to not only to friends but foes alike. Cheers!

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a glass.  Look - Pitch black body with a thick dense tan head. Possibly my favorite looking beer ever.  Smell - Strong roasted malt tones with some really dark chocolate, think like 90% cacao chocolate.  Taste - The smell translates to the taste. However, there's also hints of coffee and a mild hop finish to round it all out.  Feel - Thick body with medium carbonation. Heavy and refreshing to drink.  Overall - This was one of the first beers I ever drank. Had it at a hot 4th of July party, and absolutely hated it. Coming back to it now, and I love it. A wonderfully enjoyable stout.

Poured dark black with small tan head. Smell was roasty malt,coffee and some dark chocolate. The taste was coffee, chocolate and really roasty. I was surprised by the bitterness at the end. The feel was smooth with a little bit of dryness. Overall this was a solid RIS. For 9% ABV it hides the alcohol really well. And when you consider the availability and the price point, this is a worth the money.

poured into a 13-14oz stout glass from a 12oz bottle.  appearance: practically pitch black, very little light shines through. a small tan head appears on first pour and then becomes a slight layer.  smell: toffee, roastiness, coffee. a slight hint of dark chocolate.  taste: follows the nose fairly well. lots of coffee-like flavor, but not overpoweringly so. a hint of dark chocolate on the finish. nice dark roastiness throughout. slightly bitter but enjoyable aftertaste.  feel: smooth as butter. creamy, full-bodied. carbonated just enough to be noticeable but not enough to detract from the silkiness. very dry.  overall: one of the best russian imperial stouts i've had, and was also one of the first. i found myself comparing other RIS's to this one. i can't wait to try the barrel aged variety.

Its the best imperial stout ive tasted. Its even more amazing and smooth and creamy on draft. I only buy this beer for drinking at the casa. Ive tried other stouts and some are good but nothing really comes close. I even bought an Old Rasputin shirt im wearing now lol. Imperial stouts are way better than milk stouts in my opinion and if you try this one it will always be in your top 3.
One of my top two or three favorites of readily available national RIP’s. Great beer.Smooth, great black pour with a good head and lacing that stays are around.

Black as oil with a creamy head. Smells of coffee, chocolate, molasses. Slightly bitter taste to mask the high alcohol content, nice finish with no aftertaste. Liquidy mouth-feel like all stouts with a high alcohol content. A superb beer for cold weather in Northern California!
Holy moly.

Oily black in color. Poured with a tall, creamy, espresso beige foam with medium light retention. Intense, earthy, dark roasted malt, sweet dark malts, dark fruit and dark chocolate aromas with an underlying booziness. Medium bodied with medium light carbonation. Smooth, slightly oily, creamy feel through the middle followed by pleasant boozy warmth to the finish. Sweet dark malt flavors up front that slowly transition to intense roasted maltiness. Medium bitterness through the middle followed by bitter , charred malt overtop emerging boozy warmth. Finished semi-dryly with grainy, dark malt flavors followed by dark roasted maltiness that transition to mellow, burnt malt notes. An intensely malty experience that is best sampled on the warmer side. Very tasty with fabulous malt complexity.

Looks very dark poured into a shifter. Some dark brown foam head that quickly dissipated into minimal lacing.  Smells heavy with alcohol, chocolate, and toast at the front.  Tastes after the nose with caramel and toast at the back.  Mouthfeel is smooth with a bit of carbonation, nearly perfect with Russian food.  Overall great, a personal favorite with Russian tea cakes.  Pairs well with strong cheese, Russian tea cakes, and chocolate mousse.
Stouts are not a style I buy frequently unless I'm in a certain mood. My experience with them is somewhat limited but this was a delicious beer.
Dark and thick and bitter. Exactly what you'd expect of a stout. Espresso like flavor. Also a hefty drink at 321 calories a bottle so definitely not for dieters.
I always love tasting a new flavor in a stout. This ones got notes of like dark, rich fruit. It's so tasty. Sometimes a stout can be too bitter but this is delicious. Really good yo

Bottle dated 10/03/2017. CBF Tulip.  A: pours an opaque black with a finger and a half of gorgeous frothy, sandy head. Rings of lacing down the glass.  S: deep, sweet, complex aromatic roast. Surprisingly jammy, fruity, herbal, hoppy. A lot like Narwhal in that respect - perhaps more so for the perceived berry-like aspect here.  T: wow. Intense hoppy, toasty, sweet maltiness. Characterized by a tart, berry-like sweet hoppiness and a lingering roasty bitterness.  M: full-bodied, slick, with virtually no carbonation.  O: I had this a decade ago as a taster at a winter farmers market and was blown away. I have been looking for it since, and I can see why. Truly superb. I honestly think I like this better than Narwhal or Blackout.

As an Eastern Orthodox adherent may I ask that the Lord look upon you and may His face shine upon you. If you're picking up this brew, then I think he is and has been. This is good, throaty stuff for true believers. If you're a casual, then retreat to your Bud Light. If you're ready for a hoppy martyrdom, then jump in.

The smell is surprising for a stout! Pours with hardly any head, creamy light brown colour. When inhaled deeply can smell the alchohol, but there is actually an overpowering fruity citrus to the scent which I find very surprising. a slight bit of roastyness there, and a good amount of fresh smelling hops bitterness. Smells more of a black IPA than a stout.  Tastes like a black IPA as well, which I love! A huge a roasty caramel flavour on the start, with slight malt flavour finishing in intense hoppy, dry bitterness. Tastes way better than it looks in my opinion! I would go ahead and call it a black double IPA personally! Really find it tastes and feels more like a roasty IPA than a stout! Very bitter and floral hops tastes for a stout.  Bottom line: This is surprisingly really good in a way I didn't expect at all, I'm glad I got a whole growler!!!

Pours an opaque dark, dark brown, with a thick tan head, does not dissipate quickly. First scents of a bitter dark chocolate, a lingering malty aroma as you sip. Flavor is chocolate, not sweet but not bitter. A weighty, pleasant mouthfeel. I've learned to take my time with this one, and I enjoy it.

Updating my ranking by adding a few notes. This beer is excellent in so many ways. Look is spot on with dark brown to black color with a long lasting khaki head. Smell is coffee, cocoa, earthy hops. Taste follows nose with a burst of dark fruit and roasted malt. A bit dry in the end. Wish it was a little more full bodied, but definitely holds up. Overall, still excellent and still one I enjoy very much. No tricks, no frills, just good beet.

Pitch black other than light penetrating through the very bottom, showing dark brown highlights. No crown formed other than just a ring attached to the glass and a large misty island.  The nose brings unsweetened chocolate, fudge and slight coffee.  The taste brings in a huge breadiness. It mixes with the unsweetened chocolate and fudge notes.  Super dried out throughout entirety. Carbonation leaves you burping throughout.

Poured from a bottle into a glass.  Overall: top notch. Excellent, bold, and complex brew. In the words of my Bro, it tastes like leather and man.  Look: super dark. Barely a ruby glimmer can be seen at the edge of the glass when held to the light. A sticky brown froth-like head that sticks everywhere. Smell: hops, dark roasted malts, an acidic char, cocoa powder, Turkish coffee. Taste: follows the nose. Dark charred malts, an acidic high note, grass, hay, and leather. Espresso. Some sweet notes. Feel: full body, low to moderate carbonation, a little chewy.

Dark brown pour with caramel-colored thick head that holds up well. Smell has hints of chocolate. The taste is fantastic, with a great blend of chocolate, caramel, and coffee flavors. Fantastic texture, with just the right amount of thickness. Drinks smooth. Overall an awesome RIS.

DATE: December 15, 2017... OCCASION: relaxing after the annual Frost ugly holiday sweater party... GLASSWARE: Corsendonk stemmed tulip... builds a three-finger brown slushy head that forms a mesa at its center... the pile of brown head sits atop the crypt-like blackness... thick cocoa intensity early, with a soft lactic enticement... roasted malts mesh with oats, coffee bean, and earthy vegetable... first sip is potent, thick, warming, lasting, resounding with a molasses-like consistency... slightly boozy, but not alcoholic.... strong, dry, and commanding... sweet, almost puckering at 9%, textured enough to leave a tobacco-like herbal finish... after passing this by in stores for years, I am happy to have made its intimate acquaintance... the smears of lacing articulate a quality product, with heavy clouds around the glass... huge payoff, and one that drinks like a scotch...

Pours a pitch black coloration with a medium creamy head. Smells of roasted coffee, caramel and a hint of dark fruits. Taste follows the nose with a rich roasted coffee taste and notes of sweet caramel malts, dark fruits and chocolate, with a nice bitter finish. Mouthfeel is nice, but could honestly be better, which is my main complain here. Does not top Narwhal for me, which has a better mouthfeel and is more chocolate-forward, with a milder bitterness.
Thin head, but nice lacing. Little aroma. Malty. Amazing flavor. Hints of chocolate in the retronasal. Mild alcohol taste, esp for a 9%. Had a bottle in LA.

If its possible to make a better RIS i dont know how they would do it. If you are a stout/porter fan you owe it to yourself to get this one. On par with A Sammy Smith Oatmeal Stout and thats my favorite stout. Wow. Great job
Simply one of my favorite beers. Sometimes hard to find because of it's distributors.

A - Jet black with little translucence in the pour. Minimal head and little lacing. S - Complex notes of dark fruit, roasted malt/grains, and just a little chocolate. T - Everything, just like the nose, is very, very well balanced. M - Almost my level of medium bodied. Definitely lingers for a bit and carbonation is good. O - Like someone else just said below since I won't say it better "A definite standard for non-barrel aged stouts." I'm more of a barrel-aged stout fan, but this is what the best of bases tastes like. Get it again as a good standby.
Deep, rich, flavors of fruit, malt, chocolate - none overbearing, such an enjoyable sip. Looks and feels exactly how you'd want and expect. A definite standard for non-barrel aged stouts.

12oz bottled 5/8/17 poured into a tulip pint glass at fridge temp 9% ABV. The beer pours dense black with mocha brown head. The head recedes to a ring and patchy islands leaving lacing from the top of the glass to the bottom. The aroma is roast malt, coffee and a hint of dark fruit. The taste is semisweet dark fruit at first that transitions to big roasty bitterness on the end. Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied, adequately carbonated, smooth and dry. Overall, excellent. This is a standard bearer for the style.
Lots of flavours!
Black like coffee with amble carbonation, this stout has many complex but subtle flavors...I like this very much!

Poured into chilled glass mug from two 12 oz bottles. Colour is near black with a dark tan head. Smells of dark fruit and roasted malt. Taste has a nice mix of coffee, rich dark fruits and a touch of licorice. Mouthfeel is a little on the heavy side but still good. Very good stout. Prost!

Poured into a perfect pint glass.  Appearance - two fingers of thick, creamy, tan head. Very dark, almost black, with a very deep ruby hint when held up to light. Nearly opaque. Lacing sticks to the side of the glass in a uniform wall.  Smell - the aroma is almost sweet, with notes of darker fruit, dates, currant, and raisin. A little smokey. Black coffee and toffee.  Taste - malt is very forward with a taste of dark chocolate cocoa, leading to a lingering aftertaste of burnt popcorn kernel. Moderate bitterness.  Mouth feel - high carbonation, with a medium to full body. Smooth finish. More viscous than your average beer, but not as full bodied as I would have expected.  Overall - I'm not typically a stout kind of girl, so maybe this one is going to be victim of the style. Don't get me wrong, this is a really solid stout - you won't be disappointed. But there's nothing about it that "wows" me. At 9.00% abv this packs a good punch, and it is especially drinkable for such a dark beer.
On Nitro

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a 12 ounce tulip glass. Very dark with a rich malty smell. Generous head with decent lacing. My first impression is that it tastes almost like a barrel aged stout. After enjoying some fresh Narwhal (which I truly enjoy) I have to say that this is a step above and worth paying a little more for. It is very well balanced and really shines for me on the finish. The front end is as it should be and the back end has a great combination of a slight sweetness mixed with a very enjoyable booziness. I only purchase it once or twice a year but when I do I am happy that I did.

Pours thick with a foamy lasting head - from the bottle.  Smells foremost of licorice (not particularly my favorite) followed by dark fruity notes and a touch of roast.  The taste is so satisfying. Roast is much more prevalent and softened by sweet malts and dextrins. Many subtleties from unsweetened cacao, to chicory and on to dates/raisins. Some floral notes too. Definite hop presence and roast balance out the sweetness and allow this beer a beautiful balance.  Mouthfeel is full, but not overwhelming.  Overall this beer is a standard for a reason. Totally approachable and totally drinkable despite its 9% ABV. Would have no problem drinking a 4 pack in a night... other than knowing how unproductive my tomorrow would be.

Beer pours black coffee color with a large tan head. The smell has chocolate, coffee and alcohol notes. The flavor is strong coffee and the alcohol really comes through. It's a smooth beer but leaves a strong taste in the throat. A really good stout but their are better out there.

From notes 2/3/12: Pours midnight black but when inspected closely is found to be very dark brown with a ruby hint when held to the light. The pour produces a huge, lasting, tight, cottony, mocha head which leaves thin, sticky lacing. Aroma is cocoa, coffee, dark bread, roast and earthy hops. Taste is semi-sweet dark chocolate, toffee, roasted/burnt malt, dates, figs and fruit cake with coffee in the finish where it blends with hop bitterness and peppery spice. Heavy bodied, complex and incredibly good!
It has just a hint of bourbon, but not overpowering. It is a good beer to have a second one.
The best of it's kind.

Poured from fridge temp. Pours jet black with light tan head. Nose is smoke, tobacco, roasted malts, and licorice. Very strong and nice. Taste is a smack in the face. Crazy coffee, bitterness, smoke, molasses, tobacco, and chocolate. Bitterness lingers on the palate. Mouthfeel is thick and creamy. Amazing.
Decent every day beer. A little sweet, but nice chocolate followed by a expresso aftertaste.

Pours pitch black with a massive light brown head. Smells of burnt malt, caramel, and some earthy hops. Nothing super outstanding, but it just smells right, ya know? Taste is dark chocolate bitterness, a strong malt profile, and some warming alcohol. Chocolate comes through more as it warms up, it's a wonderful sipper. Feel is sticky, smooth, and medium-bodied. A solid imperial stout, and great for the price point.
pure black, with an obnoxious head smells of malt and caramel taste is of a dark chocolate bar with coffee notes points off feel for said obnoxious head overall, king of stouts as far as i can tell

Ok, I will be the first to admit that I am not a skilled reviewer. Nevertheless, I have to submit something to show my appreciation and admiration for this wonderful brew.  Imagine putting into a blender- deep dark chocolate, dates, raisins, prunes, a touch of cream, and the richest of coffees and toffee. Then store it all in a cask of charred oak until it becomes something mortal man does not deserve!  That is the best that I can do. Perfection in a glass!
beautiful dark brown color, small head, but laces well. strong coffee taste (which I'm partial to), thick feel. High ABV so I only have one in a day.
Excellent dark beer. One of my favorites. Very smooth to drink, strong and hearty. Feels like you just had a meal when you drink a bottle. Tasting notes of chocolate and coffee.

A- Pours with a very thick consistency, like motor oil and is super brown/black in color.....completely opaque as well! The head is super creamy, has excellent retention, eventually settling down to a thick layer over the brew (starts out about one finger thick), and is very dense like a meringue top. Obviously the carbonation is much too tough to see and there is a super sticky and thick lacing that sticks to the side of the glass. Very nice looking overall!  S- Loads of deep dark chocolate, black coffee, creamy almond like liqueur, burnt black/chocolate malts, hints of licorice, rye bread and yeast, along with slight rummy vanilla/caramel sweetness near the finish. It doesn't have the traditional Imperial Russian stout booziness as its well hidden in the aroma overall!  T- This is quite a nice Imperial! The booziness hits the palate immediately and then quickly settles down, only after hitting the top of the palate with hopped bitterness! Again, there is a great deal of cocoa powder, french press black coffee astringency, 90%+ chocolate, creamy yeast, burnt brown sugars, licorice Earthiness, blackstrap molassess, perhaps of nuttiness, charred vanilla creme, and a hopped bitterness that lingers on the palate long after the taste.  M/O- Rich and full bodied, with smooth velvety carbonation! The problem, and this really isn't a problem, is how easy drinking this is and I'd be afraid of enjoying one too many before it creeps up on me.....right in the Rasputin! The booze is superbly well hidden throughout once your palate accustoms to the initial taste. Love the heavy coffee/chocolate/cocoa character and most definitely recommend this one to any Stout lovers! Will be getting again!

355ml bottle poured into a snifter.  Crude black in color with very thick silky dark brown head, the head withstands with good retention before slowly subsiding to an eternal foamy crown that won’t die down and leaving lots of lacing patch and spot.  Very rich chocolate that tends to be dark rather than milky along with cocoa nibs, black coffee with slight sourness, and roasted take the lead. Then I get fudge, dark bread, cocoa powder, burnt caramel, sweet dark fruits, mint, and licorice. Lightly charred nut too and a little bit smoked but not in kind of meaty also with some significant touch of leafty and grassy hop.  It is heavily roasted through the palate sensation together with notes of dark chocolate, cocoa nibs, cocoa powder, black coffee with slight sourness, fudge, dark bread, burnt caramel, sweet dark fruits, mint, licorice, charred nut, slightly smoked, all mostly from malt. Hop is there so upright with its leafty, herbal, and persistent grassy bitterness that comes from both hop and roasted malt.  Rather full body with smooth and just slight viscous mouthfeel but somehow a bit watery, the carbonation is low while the feeling is well-rounded and good to carry the complexity and intensity of all the characters. Finish is very dry and pleasant.  Great RIS and perfect example to the style, it is rich, deep, and complex. Apart from its typical deep yet intense roasted, coffee, and chocolate, you will also get so bold hop characters of grass, herbal, and big bitter kick.

Big bottle from LCBO. Dark opaque beer with a beige head.  Nose is roasted malt, caramel, dark chocolate, dark coffee.  Taste is kinda harsh, not that much sweetness, hell of a roasted malt, ashy, kinda unbalanced, would need some aging.

Looks dirty and dark. Is it liquid soil? Smells like licorice and dark fruits maybe some cherry. Taste explodes in bitterness and burned malt. Just the faintest touch of sweet, from the darkest of chocolates. It was like I chewed on some ground coffee. Alcohol notably present in the long lingering aftertaste. Overall quite impressive, I love this beer and will happily drink it again!
It's potent kick is masked by a lovely classic stout aroma.
It is delicious, bitter and dark. No sweetness not balance out the bite, high for myself is a downside.

Was fortunate enough to find this brew at a local craft beer store. Had to try it and it was fantastic! The color was a deep dark richness and it poured beautifully. The foamy head was a creamy beige. The first taste was phenomenal with chocolate and coffee overtones, lingering on the palate. It was better than I had expected. The overall finish was excellent for the taste lingered on after I had finished. I definitely want to have another.
Nothing really stood out good or bad. Nice color, decent smell, some malty character, but nothing about it was outstanding.

It's a rather standard but still attractive deep brown (almost black) with a dense but thin head. The head has a creamy feel on the tongue, and the body is pleasantly smooth and milky. This is likely one of the best-feeling beers I've ever had. That said, I couldn't get around to liking the taste, which is chocolaty but also somewhat sour and stale. It smells strongly of chocolate as well, though a little flatter than most beers of its kind that I've tried. This has the formula to be a favorite beer of mine, but it ended up disappointing me.
Amazing strength of character. Slightly bitter semi-sweet taste. Very good in the glass.
Great taste! Loved this stout.

Pours medium into a fifteen ounce mug the same temperature as the beer. Appears nearly jet black and opaque with a one and a half finger creamy tan head. Some ruby highlights. Nice sticky lacing.  Smells of roasted coffee, bakers chocolate and dark roasted malts. Touch of alcohol. Ripe dark fruits. Hints of tobacco barn and smoke.  Taste follows the nose with a balanced blend of sweetish chocolate, expresso coffee and roasted malts. Deep luscious dark fruit like plum, raisins and dates. The bitter is in there but almost completely lost in the in the mix. Silky on the palate with perfect carbonation. Sweet up front then boozy with a good hop finish added to the dark roasted malts. Silky on the palate with perfect carbonation.  Overall this has to be one of the top imperial stouts. I enjoyed it immensely. Cheers!!

Had this beer at the 2015 and 2016 Laganitas Beer Fest Such a thick and sweet creamy beer with heavy coffee and chocolate tones, really enjoyed sipping this ice cold offering in 100+ degree weather.  I recently tried this beer on Nitro over at 99 Beers on the wall in Santacruz, It's much better on nitro, makes that thick creamy beer go down so easily, and just provides a totally new experience with the beer!

The beer is black with an extremely tan foamy head that does not die. The beer smells of coffee and char. The beer has a heavy malt and coffee flavor that is followed by a bitterness on the tongue. The beer is creamy. Really enjoyed it.

Amazing taste with coffee/toffee/dark and roasted malts flavors thrown into a great hops balance. Leans toward the dark in flavoring...... as it should since it's in the stout family.....killer stuff!

Enjoyed on draft in taster glass. Poured dark black with a persistent foam that took several seconds to lift into a thick sticky head that remained on top of the beer and on the sides of the glass as I drank the beer down. Smells thick of rich malt and lightly of malt. Taste is slightly bitter and sweet with a delicious mix of coffee flavor and hops playing well together. The feel is rich and smooth on the tongue. Body is fairly heavy, but not overwhelmingly so. This beer has a near completely perfect mix of everything from the smell, taste, and body which makes for a fantastic beer that thoroughly pleases.

It poured pitch black with a thick one inch foamy head that didn’t want to die untl the last drop was gone from the glass. The lacing is thick and clingy. The smell is roasted malt with coffee mixed really well. The taste is bitter but very sweet having the hops combine nicely with the roasted malt and coffee. The beer gets sweeter as it goes. There is an ever so slight caramel in the taste as well. The palate is medium to thick bodied. Overall, this beer never ceases to amaze me no matter how many times I have it.
Pour in pint glass, dark with one inch of head. Charred and toffee nose. Vanilla, charred wood, hoppy and espresso taste. Overall, a typical imperial stout but lack complexity.

I was completely excited seeing this stocked here in the East Coast and decided to give it a try.  Please, PLEASE if the brewers are reading this, you need to dial the hops back at least 50% from where they are now. There is nothing more disappointing than having a great midnight beach hang with the pooper, place the snifter out, pour what looks to be a fantastic beer with great head & lacing, only to smell hops right off the bat.  Then the taste, come on man. Please. Someone please stop with the hops already. An Imperial Stout should be bready, malty, with some dark cherry, plums, raisins maybe, with subtle licorice and coffee overtones, but never, EVER hoppy!  Thank God I brought a variety down to the beach with me. If have been pissed to have to walk back and get more beer.
Very dark. Smells and taste of coffee but just the right amount. I like how smooth the it goes down. Very drinkable...

I read several of the reviews on this beer. Ive had other imperial stouts and was excited to try this one. I couldn't be more disappointed. The feel and look are fine for an Imperial Ale, but my overall score is based on the taste, which is the most important factor. It's way over-hopped so it drowns out any subtle flavors from the malts. Stouts, in my opinion should be malty to balanced, with the bitterness coming from the roasting of the malts rather than an over abundance of hops. It's as if they're trying to turn it into the dark version of an IPA, an IDA? IPAs are fine if that's what you go for, but when I drink stout ale I want to enjoy balanced malty goodness, not Christmas tree flavored brew. This is just a terrible ale. Brewers shouldn't feel they need to add a ridiculous amount of hops just because the alcohol content is high. This ale would probably be pretty tasty if they dialed the hops back a bit. I didn't give it a 1 because I would reserve that for Coors and Budweiser.

Y'all mutha fuckas is crazy! This is a bad beer! All that time to age and develop complexity and add wood and vanillins and all you get is hot, burnt alcohol and char. They need to throw away the recipe and start again because this is a complete dog.

Had high hopes but just didn't enjoy this - not the look in the glass (little head), the aroma, not the taste... nor the finish. Maybe was an old bottle (didn't see a date). Might give it another chance but for now this is a NO from me. Sorry Raspy!

Appearance very black, 2 finger head that dissipates to a 1/4" with excellent lacing. Smell is fruity and malty. Taste is strong coffee, subdued chocolate with a dry finish. Feel is medium thick and smooth. Overall, a very satisfying and balanced brew. Wife really likes it, and she doesn't like most imperial stouts. Will be getting some more of this. About halfway thru my second, starting to feel the buzz. I like it.

Bomber purchased at the LCBO; bottled Oct 28 2016 and served slightly chilled. Not the first time I've enjoyed this stout, though it is the first time I've had a chance to review it.  Pours black as night, with roughly one inch of frothy, tan-coloured foam seated atop. Ungodly retention; the head gives up virtually no ground for more than 15 minutes, though it does take on a smoother, creamier, lumpier appearance - as its big, soapy bubbles burst, gradually being replaced from below by tiny, finer gauge bubbles. Beautiful lacing, too; this is a visually-stunning brew. The aroma reveals this to be a rather well-hopped stout, with big leafy, earthy hop notes coming through almost as clearly as the rich, roasted malts themselves. Black coffee, molasses, dark chocolate and cocoa figure in strongly, with accents of licorice, dates, raisin, alcohol and smoke supplying added depth of character to the nose.  A genuine treat to sip. Big roasted malt flavours dominate the profile right off the bat - espresso coffee and baker's chocolate blend together with a mix of caramelized sugar and molasses sweetness. Hints of date, prune and vanilla also come through by the midpoint, with the sip rounded out by herbal licorice, earthy pine resin and leafy hop bitterness on the back end. Finishes bitter, with coffee grounds and earthy hop flavours fading as you approach the dry-ish aftertaste. Medium-full in body, with restrained carbonation that gently prickles the palate and provides a slight bite; the overall texture is quite smooth, luscious and creamy. Pleasurable and fulfilling to sip.  Final Grade: 4.35, an A grade. Old Rasputin is exactly what an imperial Russian stout should be - rich, smooth, balanced, and intense. When I first tried this imperial stout a few years back, I definitely liked it, but not to the extent where I considered it one of the best - however, this follow-up sampling has converted me into a true believer. The exquisite balance achieved between the roasted malts and sturdy hop notes is nothing less than a thing of beauty. There may very well be better stouts out there, but that doesn't diminish what North Coast has managed to accomplish. One of the grand-daddies of them all; if you haven't tried Old Rasputin, do yourself a favour and take whatever steps are necessary to correct that.

It's a heavy handed beer that knocks you out with a strong nose of raspberry and molasses, approaching a wine bouquet. Rich head, dark purple virtually opaque color.  Coffee on the front but not overly bitter. At first sip, I thought it slightly sweet. Soon enough, taste diffuses into rich body of aforementioned java.  Incredibly smooth.

L - Pitch black with generous tan head. Looks enticing. S - Rich chocolate malt wafts from the glass. My mouth is watering. T - Chocolate, malt, roasted flavours abound. Dry alcohol finish lingers. F - Feels warm and dry on the tongue. O - Very nice Russian imperial stout.
Nice dark pour and pleasant aroma. Complex flavors and characters with a slightly crisp finish. Each drink introduces new flavors. Well done.

I am baffled as to how it has taken me until now to review this beer. I wish that it were as easy as blaming it on The Bottle Backlog here at Chez Woody, but this was a fairly fresh bottle that I recently scored simply to drink & review. I am scratching my head in response.  From the bottle: "Brewed in the tradition of the 18th century English brewers who supplied the Russian court of Catherine the Great."; "Old Rasputin develops a cult following wherever it goes. It's a rich, intense brew with big, complex flavors & a warming finish."  Still shaking my head, I Pop!ped the cap & began a slow, gentle pour. Once sufficiently decanted, a vigorous in-glass swirl raised three-plus fingers of dense, foamy, rocky, deep-brown head with good retention. Color was Black/Opaque (SRM = 44), allowing deep brown highlights to be visible only at the edges. Nose was smoky, with notes of coffee and especially dark chocolate brownies. To be even more precise, this smelled like liquefied chocolate brownies! Wow. No wonder this is so popular. I was impressed & I hadn't even taken my first sip of this review! Mouthfeel was big, thick & creamy, a dollop on my tongue. I just let it lie there & roll around. The dark, rich chocolaty taste was like a liquefied dessert, whether brownies, chocolate mousse, chocolate ice cream, ad chocofinitum. Wow! Finish was semi-sweet since the chocolate also had a bitter edge to it. It was just a bit much for me and left me craving something that was hop-driven. An RIS just is not my bag.

Look: Jet black with 2" caramel head Aroma: roasted barley, acrid, chocolate. A bit subdued. Taste: heavy dark chocolate, caramel sweetness, vanilla, big roasted bitterness, subtle piney hops. Absolutely wonderful, probably my top RIS at only 9%. Long bitter finish. Mouthfeel: thick and chewy, heavy carbonation.
yummy stuff here

This one has a couple years on it. L- Pours a very dark brown impenetrable to light. A one-finger, creamy, tan head with next to no carbonation. S- Roasted coffee, caramel malt, cocoa. T- Bitter coffee dominates with black licorice transitioning into bitter hop. Dark chocolate. Bitterness resinates up the nose. F- One of the best warming feeling I have had. Very slight alcohol burn. O- Awesome Russian stout. Just as they should be.
From Untappd

Poured from 12 oz bottle. Opaque jet black: I held the glass directly up to the sun and couldn't detect a glimmer through it! Head is a nice smooth frothy brown and sticks around. Aroma is an intoxicating mix of roasted coffee and bittersweet cocoa with burnt caramel and some booze. Taste is all of the above in a fairly dry package with a bit of booziness high in the back of the palate and some bitter hops lower in the back and in the finish, without much linger. Great balance. Feel is not quite as creamy as I would like for the style, but still medium to full bodied, with moderate not-too-low carbonation which I do like. It seems to get better every time I drink it. Why does a Russian or American imperial stout have to have 14% or higher alcohol to crack the BA250? I don't get it.

Pours pitch black with a nice medium head that stays nice and frothy that sticks to the glass. Lacing is thick and sticky. Has a smell of dryness and brown sugar and caramel. Moderate carbonation with decent creaminess. Carbonation weakens as it is consumed. Nice toasty malty flavor with hints of brown sugar and caramel. Moderate hop profile that has a dry finish. A very good stout, but the creaminess seemed a little thin to me.
This is my favorite beer. Love how it looks and tastes.

The label is exceptionally attractive. Pitch black pour, light colored micro foam decorated with pearls of macro bubbles. Smell is warm and ancient, yet slight, may be due to a stuffy nose. Taste is tip-of-the-tongue godly, definitely in my top 5. The mouthfeel is creamy yet refreshingly carbonated. This beer changes rapidly with exposure, new hints and undertones with separated sips, though I suggest you finish it quite quickly, as to not lose it's integrity. Great Buzz. Fantastic Beer.

Old Rapustin has been a long sought after beer for me, jokingly using the "Rasputin" name in regular conversation referencing beer purchases with my girlfriend.  This beer is black with a light light tan head (quite big) with micro bubbles in tan spraying all over as lacing.  The smell is of roasted malts, maybe some roasted chocolate, and also a bit of oats. This smell brings home the taste, a mash of roasted malts and many darker flavors while maintaining a minor hop bitterness that does not linger. Goes down easy and maintains a surprisingly light mouth feel.  I really enjoy this beer but I don't think it is something I haven't had before. It feels reallly good, by the time you are finishing number 2 (I drink fast). I think it deserves a good rating but it isn't absolutely blowing my mind. That being said it is really good, that can't be denied. I will likely buy again sometime, but it's no immediate concern. It did cost over $10 for a 4 pack. Maybe if it came in a 6, I'd feel a little more convinced. Good beer!
From tap at NCBC in Fort Bragg CA. Quite possibly my favorite nitro imperial stout! Not sweet at all with much depth to the flavor! Oh, yes, I'll have another!

Pours a pitch black with no ruby at the bottom of my tulip bowl. Barely 1 finger of a creamy light brown head. Great lacing all down the glass.  Smells strongly of stone fruits and toasted malts. A bit of an earthy aroma here as well, could this be some hoppiness?  Taste is toasted malts with some bitter from hops and a slight alcohol warming in the back of the mouth.  The mouth is the lighter side of medium with a bit of a lingering bitter finish.  Overall this is a very nicely done Russian Imperial Stout. For fans of the bigger and heavier stouts this is a must buy and try. My hat is off to the North Coast brewers for providing me and my wife with such a tasty beverage.

Very dark color with thick creamy head. This is a stout that almost anyone can drink, even if they don't like them. Strong coffee and dark chocolate flavor with a hint of malt. It has a really good bitter flavor from the coffee and dark chocolate. Many companies compare their stouts they make against this because it is so well made.
Had this at University of Beer in Davis, March 4, 2017.  Rich and dark beer, smooth drinking - it can fool you with that 9%, so don't drink too fast :)

Not going to lie bought it because the ratings on beeradvocate and the high alcohol %. I've had 4 over the last 2 weeks. The first was the best... right after work and thirsty poured a little fast but head didn't over flow glass so off to a good start. Taste like a stout should be...not as smooth as some others but still a good after work beer. Goes down easy but 1 is enough. Overall good but not good enough to buy again... too many other beers to try.

Not a "dark beer guy," but this was a party leftover which had to be consumed. Very good. Chocolate, malt and coffee tastes abound. Thin for the beer type, the ABV is completely undetectable. Thumbs up from a "hoppy" guy.

1/25/2018 12 ounce bottle on 1/18/2020. Large tan head over a dark brown body. Rich chocolate infused malty smell. Taste is much creamier and mellow with the hop bite lessened from fresh with complex dark fruit flavors making their presence known. Not boozy per se but you know you're drinking something with heft, the type of brew that Catherine the Great wanted transported large distances for her enjoyment on the long Russian nights.

Got my hands on this from Bevmo!  Poured into a snifter glass at slightly warmer than refrigerator temperature. Produced a nice tall light brown head that lasted several minutes after pouring. The color is of the same opaqueness as black coffee. Smells light roasted malts as many others have said. The taste is just great. One of the best imperial stouts I have tried. Some imperial stouts have me a bit of a bite and unwelcome aftertaste (Lagunitas Imperial Stout) but this Old Rasputin goes done very smoothly. Gives a pleasant, somewhat sweet aftertaste.  I can absolutely recommend this beverage, even for those who are not dark beer fans.

Pours black with medium, thick, brown head that lasts  Smells chocolate, roasted malts, light earthy hops and light alcohol.  Tastes toasted malts, dark chocolate, light coffee and a light bitterness. Finish is dry with a long bitter roasted linger and a hint of pine. Full body with lower medium smooth and creamy carbonation

A steady go to brew for me. Had a pint or three back in the 90s, strayed until several months ago. Goes especially well with the rain, but I plan on savoring Old Rasputin year round, until the end of Time ... Poured into a big mouth wine glass, enjoyed with a chocolate muffin.  Black with a few nice bubble streams, bubbly tan head, nice lacing too.  Smells slightly malty, with a bit of toasty bread, chocolate and coffee.  A complex taste, roasty-refined. Similar to the smell, subtle and delicious.  Truly Imperial: high quality, easily available and low cost, with a well deserved majestic reputation!

Pours total black with a shortlived espresso head. Dark chocolate and coffee with maple syrup in the nose. The taste is roasty, with rich chocolate notes. Pinesol and lemony hops provide great balance. Tobacco and leather notes in the background. The mouthfeel is medium full with a light carbonation. Moderate bitterness and dark chocolate and roasted barley in the long finish.  A very nice RIS, very much to style with plenty of complexity and balance. Any dark beer fan should seek it out.

Argh! This is so difficult and unfair from my end. I don't like stouts, unless they offer something extra (Dragon's Milk, Peche Mortel), so any rating from me on a straight forward stout is unfair. But I still try everything I can, and of course I had to try this one. Not bad, a little more tolerable than most, but I still don't get why all of dark chocolate's goodness disappears in beer. I like dark chocolate a lot. In fact, that is the only chocolate I like. But in beer, it becomes obtrusive and bitter in a bad way (unlike the bitter goodness of a double IPA). The rest is obligatory: beautiful thick head with some retention and gentle lacing, bitter (blah! to me) nose and a taste that will leave stout lovers satisfied, although it may be surprisingly watery to some. Buy it with confidence.

It pours a pretty solid black color with a giant three-plus fingers of lasting tan foam that leave heavy webbed lacing.  Nutty, lightly-roasted malts, chocolate and a little coffee stand out in the aroma. These continue to the taste where they mix with a stronger, more charred-malt flavor, some pretty strong hop bitterness, a slight vegetal flavor and a kiss of alcohol on the backend.  It's medium-to-heavy bodied with strong carbonation in play in the mouthfeel.  To me, this is a beer that would have seemed world class fifteen years ago. The vegetal note and the not-quite-perfect carbonation level knock it a bit in my scoring, but I really appreciate the charred, bitter qualities in this one and can definitely see why it's beloved.  Packaged on 12142016.

2014 bottle. Nice tan head, a ring lingers long after pouring. Smells of chocolate, dark roasted coffee, and a little smoky. Well-integrated roasted malt and dark chocolate. Fairly bitter. Thick and slick motor oil feel is exactly what I want from my imperial stouts. Pretty much a benchmark for the style.

As the first Imperial Stout I had, this is my benchmark in many ways. It's got a nice, spicy edge to it along with being thick as can be. If it has a downside it can be a bit harsh at times, definitely a sipper. But that's not really a bad thing given how strong this stuff is! Highly recommended, and I love how readily available it is. there are better Imperial Stouts out there, but few so consistently available. Especially outside of Rare Beer Festivals.

I saw this in my local liquor store and knew I had to at least grab one. I wish I had grabbed more...  Beautifully dark, thick head, and good lacing make for a visually appealing beer. The smell was distinctive to most other Russian imperials but with a good scent of booziness to tingle the nose. The mouthfeel was somewhere between medium and full-bodied but with carbonation that did not necessarily distract from the overall experience. The taste was not my best of Russian imperials I have had, but I'm pretty sure it's up there. Overall, it's an impressive beer that is well worth the hype found within this hallowed site.

Appearance: One of the best looking stouts I have ever seen. A pitch black beer that pours a huge, three finger khaki colored head that laces the glass exceptionally well. Head retention is superb, and lasts for a good 10 minutes before finally settling down.  Aroma: Lots of dark chocolate and roasted malt with hints of coffee and sweet vanilla. A tiny hint of piney hops and notions of fine tobacco. A little bit of alcohol on the nose as well. A great smelling stout.  Taste: Extremely pleasant. The flavor is predominantly consistent of a creamy, dry, dark roasted malt flavor. I'm getting bittersweet gourmet dark chocolate, rich connecticut tobacco, old leather, hints of vanilla beans, coffee and very very faint notions of sugar cookies. As it warms resinous, piney sensations from the hops assert themselves.  Feel: Full bodied with low carbonation. Smooth and velvety. Crisp (for an RIS).  Overall: Probably my favorite russian imperial of all time. Very hearty and complex, with deep notes of bittersweet chocolate and roasted malt. The mouthfeel and taste are really perfect for the style. The flavor is intricate, robust and creamy without the mouthfeel being too unctuous or slimy. Just dry enough so as to not leave you reaching for a glass of water, and crisp enough to enjoy during the warmer months without being too watery and thin.  This beer isn't for everyone but if you have a palate for dark chocolate and imperial stouts this is one you'll really enjoy.

First, I had this in a bottle (of course,) so I am rating it as that, not comparing it to a draft beer.  Local liquor store stocks these in four packs, so glad.  This is an exceptional beer. Great flavors, no weaknesses. Best all-around stout I have had. competes with my other favorite widely available stout maker, Samuel Smith.
Solid dark stout that wasn't bitter.

12oz Bottle, Purchased in Chicago, served in a 20oz Becker Glass  L: black motor oil with thick, dirty brown head that laces beautifully as it dissipates  S: hops then chocolate  T: so much going on yet so composed; smooth / effervescent / chocolate / bitter  M: medium body and surprisingly effervescent  O: complex with many of the great qualities of a russian imperial without the weight and thickness. one of the most sessionable of this variety i've had

Serving: 12 oz bottle ("11082016") poured into a 9 oz Libbey Embassy snifter glass.  Appearance: Inky black with fringes of dark brown. Builds a nice head of khaki foam that slowly recedes to streaky lace  Smell: Deeply roasted grains, light woodsmoke and emerging alcohol as it warms.  Taste: Complex malt body with layers of roasted and burnt grains, espresso and some bittersweet chocolate in the close. A healthy dose of earthy, bitter, herbal hops keeps any sweetness in check.  Mouthfeel: Full bodied and smooth with just enough carbonation.  Overall: Big, bold and complex; definitely lives up to its reputation as a classic RIS.

Pours a dark brown, and settles to a pitch black hue, with a large, thick light tan head resting on top. The head has impressive body, and real staying power, lingering long after most Stouts would have given up. Lacing is prevalent and sticky, leaving rings in the glass as I down the brew. No light passes through even when held up to direct light. The nose is much sweeter than I expected. Very fruity, up front with a softly bitter roast note hiding in the background.  The flavor is full of subtleties, with no one flavor really standing out to me. First sip, and I got a sweet malt that reminded me of bakers chocolate in a way. Next sip was full of bitter roast and hints of licorice. Each mouth full went back and forth between these two flavors, and upon swallowing I got a swell of dark fruit, presently sweet, with a warming alcohol note right at the end. The finish, in contrast to the swallow, is bitter malt that sticks to your tongue flavoring subsequent sips, altering the initial flavors. I feel as if I get hints of coffee here, but that may well be in my head as I know there is none in this fantastic beer.  The beer is a bit thinner than I expected, but still what I'd call a thick beer. There is mild carbonation that you can detect, but it in no way takes anything away from the ultra smooth feel of this beer. Overall this has to be one of the top beers I've had, Stout or not.

Weird to say that this is my "go to" imperial Stout. But it's widely available and still maintains a very high quality. Happy to introduce friends to imperial stouts using this beer. not the most rare or complicated stout out there, but for what it is, it's nearly perfect. Quality imperial Stout with a good AbV at an unbeatable price. Drink it all year round!

Dark chocolate, roasted barely, smokiness, and coffee. Beautiful to look at, and incredibly enjoyable to drink. Definitely not a place to start you dark beer journey though, that is for sure. This beer is stout.

Ah dear old friend Rasputin, a go to value beer. Pitch black with a wispy ring for a head. Smells of bakers chocolate and roasty sweetness. Taste follows, roasty sweetness, bakers chocolate, prunes/mollasses? A little more hop presence and carbonation than many popular stouts. Solid easy to find offering leaving me wondering why I pay so much for more hard to find beers.

Old Rasputin is an old favorite. Time for a review! Into a goblet...  L: Looks like expresso; super dark, but not too thick or syrupy. Tons of very fine, frothy head that acquires multiple colors, ranging from khaki to cappuccino. Great retention: the lacing formed a nice flat ring around the top of the glass with dripping tendrils.  S: Smoke is immediately apparent, followed by black olives (trust me, I used to eat these out of the can as a child) with hints of soy sauce. Once the initial impressions settle, it turns into dark roast coffee and with sweet notes of raisin, prune, and molasses, finishing in cacao nibs and blackberry jam. Probably the least sweet aroma I've ever found in a stout in my short time drinking beer. Love that dark fruit. Could do with more.  T: Upon first sip, again smoke is immediately apparent, but the salty olive flavor takes over from there, followed by prune, sea salt and blackberry (molasses and vanilla also make a short cameo). The fruit is quickly demolished by strong espresso and tobacco notes, and the finish grows increasingly dry and salty, until ending in a salty, bitter dark chocolate with more black olive and charcoal on the very end. Definitely a tasty finish, I just wish the sweeter notes in the middle lingered longer.  F: Not as thick or creamy as a typical stout, but also not very sweet, which is generally preferable to me. Perhaps this is a necessary trade-off?  O: A fantastic stout. And the only good and affordable one that's widely available (at least in California).

Pretty good stout ,poured jet black with 1 finger light cream head.  I enjoyed it but for my taste it's not world class , too thin ,too bitter and doesn't hide the booze at all.  Would drink it again but there are several ris I would go to first...

This is a go to RIS that I've enjoyed for years. The smell doesn't really give off much but the taste is where it's at. This is a benchmark for the style. Thick and rich with the ABV pretty well hidden. Taste of.....this one confuses me. It's damn good, I just can't break down the flavors. Anyhow, I always have a couple of these in the back of the fridge just in case.

Gold standard dark Russian imperial stout, creamy perfect head and just the right bite. Coffee nut notes with intense dark chocolate & bursting coffee brew flair. Complex, rich, intense and strong 9% ABV brew. Love it!  “rich, intense brew with big complex flavors and a warming finish.”

Perfectly opaque chocolate body with medium dark khaki head slowly dissipates leaving ample legs of lacing.  Taste is dark chocolate and medium roast coffee. I dunno why people are saying this tastes like espresso, the coffee flavor has that light lemon tinge I associate with medium roasts. There is plentiful hop flavor as well, however the dominant malts leave it as a sort of herbal miscellany. Unlike most imperial stouts which become sweeter as they warm, this one - due to the hops- the herbal essences become more apparent. This makes it whilst warm something like a black IPA. Mouthfeel doesn't make itself known, which is to say it's perfect.  Overall pretty good. It's a style I'm partial to as well.

This is a great classic imperial stout. I love because it's drier than most American stouts. Usually, you get the coffe/chocolate stouts on the sweet side, or a coffee/tobacco/dark fruit stout on the boozy side. But this one has a taste and finish closer to a dry stout, which is great. Like a dry stout, it's not thick either. The nose is heavy on the coffee and dark fruits: prunes and dark grapes. A bit of cacao bitterness, but no real chocolate there. The finish is very long, roasted malt and coffee, very nice. No nuttiness at all, it's actually quite agressive, that's where you can feel its American side as opposed to English stouts. Usually a heavy stout doesn't go well with a sweet dessert, but this would definitely work because of its dryness.
No bitter after taste. Delicious beer. Can't go wrong with this one and easy to get

This may be the defining beer of Russian Imperial Stouts. Poured into a Belgian style tulip/snifter glass.  L: 4.5. Jet black body, opaque, with a lingering off-tan head. S: 4 West coast hops, dark fruits and roasted malts. T: 5. Worthy of a 5. Notes of coffee and baker's chocolate. Bitter hops. Dark fruit. Caramel. Maybe a hint of tobacco. All blending together harmoniously. F: 4.25 Medium to thick bodied. Has a bit of warmth. O: 4.5. Just an excellent stout. Can't recommend highly enough. This is one you should seek out.

Color is dark, dark coffee with a nice, big, creamy, beige head that cascades bubbles as you pour and laces like a boss when it's done. Aroma is chocolate, a hint of raisins, coffee, and booze. Taste follows, but the bitter roasted coffee is more forward and the sweetness is less pronounced, although it balances nicely. Lots of alcohol burn but not unpleasant, I think it's what makes this such a good wintertime sipper. Mouthfeel is somehow thin and creamy all at the same time, with lots of carbonation and tongue numbing warmth making it a very fun drink. I wouldn't want this every day, but sipping this thing as I watch the snow coming down feels just about perfect.
Bottled dated 9/2/16

Poured from a bottle,into a Cigar City snifter.  Creamy,1 finger,khaki colored head.Jet black in color with no light coming through the glass.Hard to tell if there is any carbonation.
